case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 883, 915 to 967 and 1042 to 1044 of 1967

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 883, 915 to 967 and 1042 to 1044 of 1967 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 883, 915 to 967 and 1042 to 1044 of 1967. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgments and orders dated December 2, 5, 12 and 13, 1966 of the Gujarat High Court in various Special Civil Applications.

Government of Gujarat notified under section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act on March 10, 1965 that certain lands were needed for public purpose of construction of capital at Gandhinagar and were arable lands.

anchor.surface_text: On March 10, 1965, the Government of Gujarat numberified under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act that certain lands were needed for a public purpose, namely, the companystruction of the capital of the State at Gandhinagar and that Government was satisfied that they were arable lands.

facts.text: Government directed under section 17(4) that provisions of section 5A shall not apply to the lands notified under section 4.

anchor.surface_text: Government further directed under s. 17 4  of the Act that as the acquisition of the said lands was urgently necessary the provisions of s. 5A of the Act shall number apply in respect of the lands.

facts.text: Notification under section 6 issued on July 31, 1965, containing direction under section 17(1) enabling Collector to take possession after 15 days from section 9(1) notice.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification was followed by another on JuLy 31, 1965 under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act and it companytained a direction under s. 17  1  of the Act, enabling the Collector, on the expiration of 15 days from the publication of the numberice under s. 9  1  of the Act, to take possession of all arable lands specified in the earlier numberification.

facts.text: Both notifications signed by L.P. Raval, Under Secretary to Government, by order and in the name of the Governor of Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: Both numberifications were signed by L.P. Raval, Under Secretary to Government and were shown to be by order and in the name of the Governor of Gujarat.

facts.text: Numerous petitions filed in Gujarat High Court under Article 226 by owners of affected lands challenging validity of acquisitions.

anchor.surface_text: Numerous petitions were filed in the High Court of Gujarat under Art. 226 of the Constitution by the owners of the lands Sup, C. I,/68-3 affected by the numberifications to challenge the validity of the acquisition.

facts.text: Special Civil Application No. 1003 of 1965 was typical of all others; facts same except land details, contentions same.

anchor.surface_text: One such petition was numbered Petition No. 1003 of 1965 and it was typical of all the others. The facts in all the petitions were the same, save the details of the lands, and as the companytentions were also the same,

facts.text: Gujarat High Court pronounced common judgment on December 2/5, 1966 dismissing all petitions.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court pronounced a companymon judgment applicable to all, on December 2/5, 1966 and dismissed them. The High Court, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and the present appeals have been brought.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Article 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and the present appeals have been brought.

facts.text: Lands involved in construction of main roads and laying out of sectors in master plan covering 12 villages including Pethapur.

anchor.surface_text: who stated that the master plan was ready which involved 12 villages including Pethapur where these lands are situated. The lands were involved in the companystruction of main roads and the laying out of sectors.

facts.text: Affidavit by L.P. Raval filed on October 1, 1965 stating lands were arable and Government formed opinion on urgency.

anchor.surface_text: The first affidavit was filed by L. P. Raval, Under Secretary  Oct. l, 1965  that the lands were arable lands and Government had formed the opinion about urgency, and further that the determination of these two matters by Government was number justiciable.

facts.text: Affidavit by Executive Engineer on October 8, 1965 explaining master plan and urgency.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by an affidavit by the Executive Engineer  Oct. 8, 1965  who stated that the master plan was ready which involved 12 villages including Pethapur where these lands are situated.

facts.text: Deputy Secretary Jayaraman subjectively satisfied lands were arable and urgency existed.

anchor.surface_text: In reply another Under Secretary  Nimbalkar  filed an affidavit  Nov. 8 1965  that Jayaraman, Deputy Secretary was subjectively satisfied that the lands were arable lands and that there was urgency

facts.text: Minister-in-Charge gave instructions to Secretaries Dudam and Gill to handle urgent acquisitions without personal notice.

anchor.surface_text: The Minister-in-Charge filed an affidavit in which he said for the purpose of urgently acquiring the lands for the Capital Project, I had given instructions initially to Shri S.M. Dudam and subsequently to Shri A.S. Gill after he became the Secretary of the Revenue Department,

facts.text: S.M. Dudani was Secretary till April 2, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: M. Dudani who was Secretary till April 2, 1965 and A.S. Gill who followed him swore two affidavits.

facts.text: High Court accepted affidavits on behalf of Government regarding formation of opinion.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having before it allegations, companynter allegations and denials dealt first with the legal side of the matter. Then it readily accepted the affidavits on the side of Government.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Raval competent to sign notifications as Under Secretary under Rules of Business.

anchor.surface_text: Thus Raval was companypetent to sign the declaration as a Secretary.It is number necessary to companysider whether he can be treated as an officer duly authorised because he already had authority by virtue of his office and rule 13 of the Rules of Business

facts.text: Secretaries formed opinion on urgency and arable nature, which became Government's determination under Rules of Business.

anchor.surface_text: In our case the Secretaries companycerned were given the jurisdiction to take action on behalf of Government and satisfied themselves about the need for acquisition under s. 6, the urgency of the matter and the existence of waste and arable lands

facts.text: Arable land includes land actually under cultivation, not just capable of cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that by arable land is meant number only laud capable of cultivation but also actually cultivated. It is number arable number because it is cultivated demonstrates its nature as arable land.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals fail and are dismissed.We, however,think that this is a proper case in which there should be numberorder about companyts and direct accordingly.

holdings.text: Under Secretary L.P. Raval was competent to sign the notifications under section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act by virtue of Rule 13 of the Rules of Business made under Article 166 of the Constitution, which equates Under Secretaries with Secretaries for authentication purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Thus Raval was competent to sign the declaration as a Secretary.It is not necessary to consider whether he can be treated as an officer duly authorised because he already had authority by virtue of his office and rule 13 of the Rules of Business contemplates officers other than Secretaries. But if he did

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules of Business Rule 13 places Under Secretary on equality with Secretary for signing orders; no special authorization under Act needed as business allocated to department.

holdings.text: The formation of opinion by Secretaries Dudani, Gill, Jayaraman and Raval regarding urgency and arable nature of lands constitutes the Government's opinion under Rules of Business, rendering the directions under sections 17(1) and 17(4) valid.

anchor.surface_text: In our case the Secretaries concerned were given the jurisdiction to take action on behalf of Government and satisfied themselves about the need for acquisition under s. 6, the urgency of the matter and the existence of waste and arable lands

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits establish Secretaries' subjective satisfaction; Rules 7,10,13,15 and instructions permit Minister's oral delegation to Secretaries who act for Government; presumption of regularity and Art.166(2) apply.

holdings.text: Minister's oral instructions to Secretaries for handling urgency acquisitions without personal notice are valid under Rules of Business and supplemental instructions, as no requirement for standing orders or writing for classes of matters.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the argument of Mr. Gupte is valid.There is nothing in the Rules or Instructions which prescribes that the authority must be in writing or by Standing Orders. Standing Orders are necessary for the disposal of cases

holdings.reasoning_summary: Paragraph 4 of instructions allows Minister to arrange orally what matters or classes brought to notice; distinguishes from general standing orders under para 3; Rule 15 supplemented by instructions.

holdings.text: 'Arable land' under section 17(1) includes not only land capable of cultivation but also land actually under cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that by arable land is meant not only land capable of cultivation but also actually cultivated. It is not arable not because it is cultivated demonstrates its nature as arable land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory context of s.17(3) compensates standing crops on arable land; historical 1870 Act; dictionaries and etymology distinguish from waste/pasture; rejects narrow Bombay HC view.

holdings.text: Sections 17(1) and 17(4) of the Land Acquisition Act are not unconstitutional under Articles 14 and 19(1)(f) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Finally there remains the question of the constitutionality of sub-ss. (1) and (4) of s. 17. On this point very little was said and it is sufficient to say that the High Court judgment under appeal adequately answers all objections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court judgment adequately addresses all constitutional objections raised.

holdings.text: The notifications under sections 4, 6 and directions under section 17 invoking urgency clause are valid; appeals challenging land acquisition for Gandhinagar capital fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals fail and are dismissed.We, however,think that this is a proper case in which there should be no order about costs and direct accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All grounds rejected: authority valid, opinion formed, arable land correctly applied, constitutional challenge answered by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In support he has relied upon Emperor v. Shibnath Banerji 1 . Mr. Sens argument proceeds like this Under the Rules of Business  Rule 4  the business of Government is to be transacted in the Department specified in the First Schedule and item No. 15 covers the topic of acquisition of property and the principles on which compensation is to be determined and it is assigned to the Revenue Department. Each Department of the Secretariat consists of a Secretary to the Government  Rule 7  but the work may be divided between two or more Secretaries.

precedents.cited_proposition: Routine orders substituting police recommendation for government satisfaction render detention orders invalid
precedents.cited_holding: Direction to issue detention orders as a matter of course on police recommendation without independent satisfaction renders orders void

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed upon the decision of the Orissa High Court in Shayamaghana Ray v. State 1  that Rules 15 must prevail over the instructions. But that Rule itself provides that the Rule may be supplemented by instructions and the power so conferred was available in paragraph 4 to provide that the Minister may arrange with the Secretary of his Department what , 1  A.I.R. 1952 Orissa 230. matters or classes of matters are to be brought to his personal notice.

precedents.cited_proposition: Rules of Business Rule 15 prevails over supplemental instructions

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rejected this contention disagreeing with a decision of the Bombay High Court reported in Sadruddin Sideman v. H. Patwardhan 1 . Mr. Sen has adopted the judgment of the Bombay High. Court as part of his argument. Mr. Gupte in his reply has relied upon Guntur Ramalakhsmana and Others v. Government of Andhra. Pradesh and another 2 , Baldeo Singh and others v. State of Uttar Pradesh and others 3  and Smt.

precedents.cited_proposition: Arable land means land capable of being ploughed or fit for ploughing but not land already under the plough

precedents.citation: Guntur Ramalakhsmana and Others v. Government of Andhra. Pradesh and another 2

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupte in his reply has relied upon Guntur Ramalakhsmana and Others v. Government of Andhra. Pradesh and another 2 , Baldeo Singh and others v. State of Uttar Pradesh and others 3  and Smt. Lakshmi Devi others v. The State of Bihar and others 4  and the reasons given in the judgment under appeal. We shall first deal with the three rulings from Andhra Pradesh, Allahabad and Patna High Courts.

precedents.case_name: Guntur Ramalakhsmana v Government of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Arable land includes land under cultivation

precedents.citation: Baldeo Singh and others v. State of Uttar Pradesh and others 3

anchor.surface_text: Guntur Ramalakhsmana and Others v. Government of Andhra. Pradesh and another 2 , Baldeo Singh and others v. State of Uttar Pradesh and others 3  and Smt. Lakshmi Devi others v. The State of Bihar and others 4  and the reasons given in the judgment under appeal. We shall first deal with the three rulings from Andhra Pradesh, Allahabad and Patna High Courts. The first contains no discussion and may not be referred to here.

precedents.case_name: Baldeo Singh v State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Arable lands include land actually under cultivation as inferred from s.17(3) providing compensation for standing crops

precedents.citation: Smt. Lakshmi Devi others v. The State of Bihar and others 4

anchor.surface_text: , Baldeo Singh and others v. State of Uttar Pradesh and others 3  and Smt. Lakshmi Devi others v. The State of Bihar and others 4  and the reasons given in the judgment under appeal. We shall first deal with the three rulings from Andhra Pradesh, Allahabad and Patna High Courts. The first contains no discussion and may not be referred to here. In the case from Allahabad reference is made to s. 17   3   of the Act  already quoted  in which there is a provision that standing crops must be compensated for and it is inferred that by arable lands must be meant not only land fit for cultivation but also land actually under cultivation.

precedents.case_name: Lakshmi Devi v State of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: ploughing of them is number waste. In Lord Darey v. Askwith  Heb. 234  it is laid down as generally true that the lessee hath numberpower to change the nature of the thing demised he cannot turn meadow into arable, number stub a wood to make it pasture, number dry up an ancient pool or piscary, number suffer ground to be surrounded, number decay the pale of a park It was thus in Simons v. Norton 1  which was an action of waste for ploughing ancient meadow that Tindal C.J. made the observations which are relied upon in the Bombay case.

precedents.cited_proposition: Lessee has no power to change the nature of demised land, e.g., turn meadow into arable

anchor.surface_text: the dicta of Judges in Palmer v. McCormick 5  and Simmons v. Norton 6 . Support was then found for the view in s. 17 3  of the Act, the mention of compensation for standing crops notwithstanding. There is numberdefinition of the word arable in the original Land Acquisition Act.A local amendment includes garden lands in the expression. Now lands are of different kinds there is waste-land desert-land, pasture-land, meadow land, grass-land wood-land, marshy-land, hilly land, etc. and arable land.

precedents.cited_proposition: Arable does not mean land actually ploughed but capable or fit to be ploughed

Now lands are of different kinds there is waste-land desert-land, pasture-land, meadow land, grass-land wood-land, marshy-land, hilly land, etc. and arable land. precedents.cited_holding: Ploughing meadow land is waste because it takes years to restore sod
